The claim is false: scientists estimate termites’ carbon emissions are approximately one-tenth of those created by humans.
Professor Stefan Arndt from the Universi: s School of Ecosystem and Forest Sciences confirmed that termites only emit a tenth of the overall emissions humans create every year, in terms of anthropogenic fossil fuel emissions.
An academic study conducted by academics: Malaysia, and the UK in 2000 estimated that termites emit 3,540 teragrams, or 3.54 Gigatonnes of CO2 in a year.
The Global Carbon Project: a US-based environmental research organization, reported in a 2018 report that there were 36.2 Gigatonnes of CO2 emissions from fossil fuels and industry in 2017.
